title: SEC Charges Third Cognizant Executive With Foreign Bribery
text:
Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp.’s former chief operating officer has agreed to pay a $50,000 fine to settle civil charges that he helped authorize and conceal a bribe paid to an Indian official.

Sridhar Thiruvengadam, 55 years old, is the third top Cognizant executive to face charges after the U.S. Justice Department in February released a letter saying it wouldn’t criminally prosecute the Teaneck, N.J.-based company over an alleged bribery scheme in India.

Cognizant at the time agreed to pay a $25 million civil penalty in a separate agreement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. But federal prosecutors said they were declining to prosecute Cognizant under a leniency program for corporate Foreign Corrupt Practices Act offenders, since the company had self-reported the alleged scheme and had a strong, pre-existing compliance program, among other factors.

A lawyer for Mr. Thiruvengadam declined to comment.

Mr. Thiruvengadam’s settlement didn’t involve any new allegations against the company or any of its current executives, a Cognizant spokesman said in a statement. “Cognizant is committed to the highest ethical standards and has zero tolerance for any illegal or improper activity,” the spokesman said.

Mr. Thiruvengadam had participated in two videoconferences with three other Cognizant executives, where the decision was made to authorize a $2 million bribe, the SEC said. The bribe was paid to secure a planning permit for the construction of an office in Chennai, India, according to the agency.

The bribe, as well as a $500,000 commission to an unnamed contracting firm, was concealed in Cognizant’s books through a series of falsified contract change requests, the SEC said. Mr. Thiruvengadam helped to conceal the payments by submitting false sub-certifications in connection with Cognizant’s 2014 through 2016 audits, the agency said.

The SEC’s order on Friday charged the former executive with violating the FCPA’s internal controls and record-keeping provisions, and with causing related violations by Cognizant.

Mr. Thiruvengadam, an Indian national, served as Cognizant’s chief operating officer from 2013 until his resignation in 2018.

In February, the Justice Department and the SEC announced dual criminal and civil bribery charges against Cognizant’s former president, Gordon Coburn, and its former chief legal officer, Steven Schwartz.

Messrs. Coburn and Schwartz have pleaded not guilty to the criminal charges. Prosecutors have asked a judge in New Jersey to delay the SEC’s civil case against the former executives until after the resolution of the criminal case.

Lawyers for Messrs. Coburn and Schwartz didn’t respond to requests for comment.

The Justice Department hasn’t announced any criminal charges against Mr. Thiruvengadam.
